Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian black-figured pottery little-master cup with part of handle root; interior; rim and upper wall glazed; around tondo, dot band frieze (two rows of staggered dots) and band of alternating red and black tongues; in tondo black-figure decoration consisting perhaps of a bird (narrow tail feather, lower body, and part of one leg remaining) to right; exterior: lip glazed; handle zone reserved with red band at top and two dilute lines at bottom; lower wall glazed with narrow reserved band; handle root glazed.
Type series: Schlotzhauer little master Ionian Cup type
Curator's comments: The interior decoration is similar to that found on Gordion cups. Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the decorative motif finds parallels with his South Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9C. Type 9C cups correspond to Attic Siana, Band, and Gordion cups. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are rare at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.742) (Phase 3)
